Which one represents order of magnitude estimates
Note: [Qno: PML_726] >> The order of magnitude is preferred during initiation phase, and it has an accuracy range of -25% to 75%. This range is 100% range.

Note: [Qno: PML_794] >> PMBoK does not have separate process in the Project Cost Estimation knowledge area to develop a cost management plan. It is developed in Develop Project Management Plan process.

Note: [Qno: PML_819] >> Control Costs is concerned with Managing changes when they occur

Question: Top down estimating is also called as.

Question: You are in mid of project and customer is asking for EAC. How do you calculate Estimate at Completion(EAC)?

How would you BEST describe this project?

Answers: The project is ahead of schedule and within its budget
The project is behind schedule and within its budget
The project is ahead of schedule and over its budget
The project is behind schedule and over its budget

[Qno: PML_1369] >> Four formulae of EAC calculation: EAC = AC + ETC;
EAC = AC + BAC -EV;
EAC = BAC / CPI;
EAC = AC + (BAC - EV) / (CPI x SPI).
PMBOK (r) Guide, pp 184-185

Answers: EAC calculations either includes AC or BAC or both
ETC is never used in an EAC calculation

Is a method of predicting the life of a project
Is a method of evaluating projects when they are complete

Question: In your project, you are using cost aggregation, expert judgement, and historical relationships to establish a cost performance baseline. This is performed during:
Note: [Qno: PML_2034] >> Determine Budget is the process of aggregating the estimated costs of individual activities or work packages to establish an authorized cost baseline. Tools used in this process are Cost Aggregation, Reserve Analysis, Expert judgement, Historical Relationships, Funding Limit Reconciliation

Question: Work Performance Measurement is output of the Control Schedule Process. Which of the following are work performance measurement to the Control Schedule process?
Project A will take 2 years to complete and has NPV value $100,000 and Project B will take 4 years to complete and has NPV value $80,000. What is the opportunity cost of selecting Project A?
Note: [Qno: PML_2238] >> Opportunity cost of selecting Project A is value of Project B.

Question: Project A has a payback period of 20 months. Project B has a cost of $100,000, with expected cash inflows of $25,000 the first year and $10,000 per quarter after that. Which project would you recommend?
Note:
[Qno: PML_2240] >> Payback period of project B:
Setup cost = First Year inflow + Remaining inflow => 100,000 = 25,000 + 10,000 x months/3
Payback period (months) = (100,000 - 25,000)*3/10,000 => 3*75,000/10,000= 22.5 Months
Payback period of project A is less than the same of B therefore select project A.

Answers: Select project A because payback period is 20 month
Select project B because payback period is 19 month
Select project A because it has less payback period than B’s
Select project B because it has less payback period than A’s

Note: [Qno: PML_2244] >> In Variance Analysis you compare actual vs. planned, no prediction is involved in this tool/technique.

Question: Which type of depreciation has the least tax advantage?

Question: The difference between Verify Scope and Perform Quality Control is?

Scope verification is primarily concerned with the acceptance of work results but quality control is primarily concerned with the correctness of work results.
Scope verification is primarily concerned with correctness of work results but quality control is primarily concerned with acceptance of work results.
Scope verification is verification and scope control is validation activity.

Question: You are working on a Real Estate project. Project is nearing to completion and customer requests you to include an additional facility in the project`s final product. The BEST course of action is to:

Include the feature -- otherwise the product will not be accepted by the customer

Buyer/Seller sharing: 70% / 30%
Price ceiling: $ 60,000
Which is the PTA (= Point of total assumption, Break point) of the project?

[Qno: PML_462] >> Target Cost (TC)= 50000 (Any $ spent over it will be deducted from the seller’s profit but buyer also bear the price)
Target Profit (TP)= 5000
Target Price (TPR)= 55000
Ceiling Price (CP)= 60000 (Any $ spent over it seller will pay from his own pocket)
Buyer/Seller Ratio 70% / 30%

PTA = (Ceiling Price - Target Price)/Buyers Ratio + Target Cost
:PTA 57143

Question: You are working on a construction project and you know that same quality and grade of material can be available from many vendors. What would you include in the procurement package to ensure that offers from vendor are comparable?

Answers: The approved project scope statement, the WBS which should be broken down to Work Package level and the WBS dictionary
A statement of work describing the needs of the project in sufficient detail to enable vendors to make suitable proposals
A statement of work specifying attributes and metrics of the requested deliverables in detail to allow vendors submission of bids
The risk management plan and the reports from those risk management reviews which have been made so far

Question: You are working on a fixed-price-plus-incentive (FPI) firm contract has a target cost of $270,000, a target profit of $28,000, target price of $ 298,000, a ceiling price of $320,000, and a share ratio of 80/20. The actual cost of the project was $340,000. How much profit does the seller make?
Note:
[Qno: PML_1037] >> Target Cost (TC)= 270000 (Any $ spent over it will be deducted from the seller’s profit but buyer also bear the price)
Target Profit (TP)= 28000
Target Price (TPR)= 298000
Ceiling Price (CP)= 320000 (Any $ spent over it seller will pay from his own pocket)
Buyer/Seller Ratio 80% / 20%
Actual Cost (AC) 318000

PTA = (Ceiling Price - Target Price)/Buyers Ratio + Target Cost
:PTA 297500
Cost Overrun @ PTA = PTA - Target Cost
:Cost Overrun @ PTA= 27500
Buyer Seller (Price up to PTA will be shared by buyer & seller in agreed ratio. Any extra penny will be deducted without sharing from the profit of seller.)
80% / 20%
22000 / 5500.0 (Cost below PTA will be shared between buyer and seller)

Seller’s Profit Cut 1= 5500.00 (Profit cut associated with AC up to PTA)
Seller’s Profit Cut 2= 20500.00 (Profit cut associated with AC above PTA and less then ceiling price) (AC- PTA)
Total Profit Cut= 26000.00 (Profit Cut 1 + Profit Cut 2)
Profit paid to vendor= Target Profit - Profit Cut because of Actual cost is above than Target cost
:Profit paid to vendor= 2000.0 (Negative means loss)
Profit to buyer= PTA - Actual Cost
:Profit to buyer= -20500 Negative means loss
Total cost paid by Buyer= Actual Cost + Profit to Vendor
:Total cost paid by Buyer= 320000 Also known as cost of contract

Inform the team that they will be getting a huge bonus on successful completion of the project and divide the $30,000 at the end of the project to team members as performance bonus

Note: [Qno: PML_469] >> Special causes are difficult to identify compare to common causes.

Answers: Normal process variation is attributable to random causes and sometimes also called "white noise".
Special causes are unusual events which are difficult to foresee and mostly produce outliers.
A process can be optimized to limit the bandwidth of variations due to random causes.
Special causes are easier to predict and handle than random causes (also called common causes).

Question: Which of the following is true about accuracy and precision?
Note:
[Qno: PML_1004] >> Accuracy means that measured value is very close to the True value. Precision means the value of repeated measurement have very little scatter. PMBOK(r) Guide 4th Edition Page190
Speed of the printer is 50 pages per minute but our measurement shows that it is 49.5 pages per minute. Some times printer prints 40 PPM sometimes it prints 60 PPM although the average is 49.5 which is very near to acclaimed speed (high accuracy) but data is scattered and precision is very wide (low precision)

Answers: Precision is correctness and accuracy is consistency
Precision is consistency and accuracy is correctness
Precision is used for measuring length and accuracy is used for time measurements

Question: Which of the following statements is false

Answers: Quality control is primarily concerned with meeting the quality requirements specified for the deliverables
Scope Verification is primarily concerned with Acceptance of the deliverables
Quality control is generally performed before Scope Verification
If the project is terminated early, the scope verification is not necessary.

Question: You received an audit report from your quality audit team. This report has identified that few critical process are out of control. After this you call your project team to discuss the course of action. What describe the situation best
Note: [Qno: PML_1348] >> Out-of-control situations are identified as a part of Perform Quality Assurance, and change request goes as an corrective action input to Quality Control process. PMBOK(r) Guide 4th Edition, p. 206

Answers: You would be performing quality assurance actions
Perform quality control and revalidate the out of control process
You are performing quality assurance activities, analyzing cause of variation and identifying change requests required
You would be performing quality control activities, analyzing cause of variation and identifying change requests required

Question: To know about the stability of a process you use statistical process control chart with UCL & LCL. What is standard UCL/LCL limit in the control chart.?

Question: ARMA is a?
Note: [Qno: PML_1386] >> Auto-regressive Moving Average Model An econometric method. PMBOK(r) Guide, p. 269

Question: Quality policies and standards are established in
Note: [Qno: PML_1404] >>  Quality policies and standards are established in the Plan Quality process. PMBOK(r) Guide 4th Edition, pp. 192-194

Question: Strategic plans related to quality of project, types of project organization should undertake is under the purview of
One of the critical factors in implementing the quality plan is

Answers: Implement quality improvements as long as the benefits more than the cost of implementation
Invoice the client for all quality related activities
Implement the highest possible quality possible regardless of time it takes
You cannot do anything if top management is delaying approval of your quality budget.

Question: A control chart is being used to control a business process. As part of the control a sample of ten steps from the business process for each hour of operation are being observed. Each of the ten steps is measured, and the observations are recorded on the work sheet. The average of the ten steps is plotted on the control chart. This is called which of the following values?
Note: [Qno: PML_1624] >> Xbar is a type of control chart used to monitor a variable’s data when samples are collected at regular intervals from a business or industrial process. It is advantageous when sample size is < 11, sample size is constant and manual calculation for chart

Question: Who is responsible for determining and delivering the required levels of quality in your project?
Note: [Qno: PML_2038] >> The project manager and the project management team are responsible for managing the tradeoffs involved to deliver the required levels of both quality and grade.

Question: Schedule baseline and Risk register are inputs to:

Product Testing and Review activities are
Assumptions are

Question: You are the project manager and one of your project activities is high-risk with a very high probability that your deadline is impacted. To ensure you will meet the deadline, you agreed with the major stakeholders to reduce the scope of the project to eliminate the high-risk activity. What type of risk response strategy are you using?
Which tool you will use to create Risk Management Plan?
To perform active risk acceptance what should be done?

Answers: Develop a plan to minimize impact so that if an identified risk occurs impact can be reduced.
Develop a plan to minimize the probability of occurrence for identified risks.
Create contingency reserves in resources, money and time.
Make additional resources available to speed up the project.

Question: In your project you noticed that people can leave due to low morale and motivation. In this context low morale and motivation is an example of
Note: [Qno: PML_728] >> A risk trigger is an indication that the risk is about to occur or has occurred.

Question: You recently completed a project phase and decide to do one party with team members at weekend. This is an example of which risk response strategy?
Which of the following is true statement about risks?
Note: [Qno: PML_750] >> Only this is the only correct statement.

Answers: Risk identification happens in all the phases of the project.
Risk register has list of only expired risks
You should take action only when risk has occurred

Question: Which of the following is an output of the Identify Risks process.
Note: [Qno: PML_752] >> Risk Register is the only output of the Risk identification process.

Question: With triangular distribution, the low, likely and high values are 20, 30 and 40, respectively. The mean is _____.

Note: [Qno: PML_991] >> Risk register is updated when trigger for risk occurs.

Answers: Risk Management Plan is an output of Plan Risk Management process
Risk Management Plan will be updated when the trigger for a major risk occurs
Risk Management Plan includes the categories of risk, their definition and Definition of risk probability and impact
Plan Risk Management is an input to all the remaining Risk Planning processes

Question: Where do you maintain low probability low impact risk, so that you can monitor them from time to time but do not waste much time on those.
Note: [Qno: PML_1167] >> A watchlist is the place to keep risks that don’t have a high enough probability or impact to make. But they still need to be monitored. By recording the risk in a watchlist, you will have a reminder to check to be sure that circumstances haven’t changed as your project goes on. That should give you enough time to come up with a risk response strategy if circumstances change as time goes on.

Answers: In the Probability and Impact Matrix
In the Monte Carlo analysis report

Question: You are working onsite with your customer and you have identified an opportunity to potentially increase the project’s value. Which of the following is an example of enhancing that opportunity?
Note:
[Qno: PML_1193] >> There are four things you can do with any opportunity.
1- You can exploit the opportunity by making sure you do everything to take the advantage of it.
2- You can share the opportunity by working with another company in a way that gives you a win-win situation.
3- You can enhance the opportunity by figuring out a way to increase its value.
4- Accept the opportunity as it is and move, if you cannot take advantage of the opportunity

Answers: By forming a partnership with another company, the project’s value will increase for both companies
By taking additional actions, you increase the potential reward without reducing its probability
By taking out insurance, you can reduce potential costs to the project
By documenting the opportunity in the register, you can keep track of it and ensure it gets exploited

Question: A project manager uses a facilitator to gather opinions from experts anonymously. What risk identification tool or technique is being performed?
Note: [Qno: PML_1203] >>  The Delphi technique is used  to get opinions and ideas from experts. This technique  uses a facilitator and he questionnaires to ask experts about important project risks. Answer is taken from experts and circulated again among experts anonymously so that experts can give unbiased genuine feedback.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a tool or technique of Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis?
Note:
[Qno: PML_1216] >> Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis is all about prioritizing each risk based on probability and impact. Perform Quantitative Risk Analysis is about quantitative decision making, EMV analysis is part of it.
Remember, quantitative means numbers and qualitative means judgements!

Question: You are project manager of a software project and you have outsourced one component to the subcontractor. Based on the input received in last meeting you found that there is only 30% probability that subcontractor will be able to deliver you the component on time. And if he fail to do so it will cost you $10,000 extra to your engineers to rewrite the component. And $15,000 business will be lost due to delay in project. While discussing this problem with your technical leader he comes up with an idea that similar kind of ready made component is available at some site and using this will save project around $6,000. But there is 60% probability that our team can take the advantage of that. What is the EMV of this risk?
Note:
[Qno: PML_1219] >> To calculate the expected monetary value (EMV) of a set of threat and opportunities, multiply each probability by its total cost and add them together.
Cost of Threat = $10,000+$15,000 = $ 25,000
Probability of occurring risk 70% (100-30= 70%)
EMV of this threat = 70% x 25,000 = - $17,500
Cost of Opportunity = $6,000
Probability of occurring risk is 60%
EMV of this opportunity= 60% x 6,000 = 3,600
Total EMV of risk = -$17,500 + $3,600 = - $13,900
Cost of a threat is negative, and the cost of an opportunity is positive.

Question: You are working on a pharmaceutical project and you identified that due to inefficient distillation process 20% of the chemical would be wasted therefore you ordered extra 22% chemical for the process so that project won’t face the delay because of reordering. This is what type of risk response strategy?
Note: [Qno: PML_1224] >> You are taking action to mitigate the impact of risk.  Risk mitigation means taking some sort of action that will minimize the damage, if risk occurs. Or reduce the probability of happening the risk

Question: Who is a risk owner?
Note: [Qno: PML_1234] >> In a risk register, every risk should be assigned to a person and that person is responsible for watching the sign of risk, updating the response plan, and initiating corrective and preventive actions. This person is called risk owner.

Answers: The person who is responsible for the response plan for the risk
The person who meets with stakeholders to explain the risk
The person who makes a risk happen
The person who monitors the watchlist that contains the risk

Question: A contingency plan is:

Answers: A planned response that defines the steps to be taken so that any risk can be avoided
A planned response that defines the steps to be taken if an identified risk event should occur.
A reserve used to allow for future situations which may be planned for only in part.

Question: On your project you buy insurance for all the equipments what type of risk response plan this is?
Management reserves are used to handle which type of risk?
Note: [Qno: PML_1856] >> Unpredictable, unthought, unplanned risk, disaster should be managed using management reserve. Special approval is required from management to utilize this fund

Note: [Qno: PML_2451] >> All are part of Project Risk Management except Solicitation.

Question: Alan is developing prototype for his customer. What is the purpose of prototype?

Prototypes are mostly developed toward the end of a design or build phase.
Prototypes increase the risk of misunderstandings between developers and users.

Question: The scope management provides

A baseline to evaluate potential scope changes.

Question: Collect Requirements is:
Note: [Qno: PML_821] >> Collect Requirements is progressive elaborative process and collects various type of requirement from various stakeholders so that product/service/result can be generated as defined.

Answers: Developing a plan from major stakeholders
Developing options how to implement the requirement into system
Formalizing acceptance of the project scope
Developing a written requirement documentation as the basis for future project decisions

Question: Which of the following is true regarding Control Account?

It is a quality control tool for controlling the defects to minimize delivered defects
It is the major accounting book where all the cost details are entered for an active account

Note: [Qno: PML_1347] >> Stakeholders can give input but scope baseline should be created by Project Team.

Note: [Qno: PML_1399] >>  Breaking the work down to the work package level. PMBOK(r) Guide, p. 116

Answers: Breaking down the work into increments of less than 40 hours each
Breaking down the work to the lowest level of detail possible
Breaking down the work by functional area
Breaking down the work to the work package level

Question: Project scope is:

Question: As a project manager for a high visibility project you received a preliminary press release for your approval before distribution. You are expected to approve the release without comment. While reviewing you identified a major discrepancy regarding some key project financial estimates that may mislead the audience. As a project manager on this project, giving current conditions, it is your responsibility to:

Answers: Approve the release but send a memo to the sponsor advising that you are aware of the discrepancy.
Inform the project sponsor of the discrepancy and refuse to approve the release.
Completely rewrite the press release and include the correct information.

Question: You & your friend are working with two different competing companies and both are bidding for same project. Your friend has given you some internal bidding related information. What should you do?

Answers: Tell your friend that they should not submit the proposal
Suggest your management that we should not bid for the project
Inform the friend that he should not providing confidential information and check with your management that whether some body else can work on this proposal.
Ask a fellow project manager to work on the proposal

Question: You are managing a project in a foreign country. In this country there is a normal practice for business people to exchange gifts whenever a new project is awarded. Therefore company has guidelines to accept and pay gift of certain range without approval. You given a gift to your customer. Now customer is giving you the gift of higher value than your gift. What should you do now?

Answers: Tell your customer to give the gift to your manager.
Ask your customer to give you the gift of lower or equal value than allowed limit in your organization.
Refuse the gift graciously, explaining your company’s policy
Contact your company’s management and seek for assistance

Question: As a project manager you can assign any one of two team members to a highly confidential task. Both are equally capable, but one of them is a member of your in-group. To the other one, you have far more distance. How should you behave?

Answers: You disclose the situation to stakeholders and solicit a joint decision.
You take the person not in your in-group to avoid misunderstandings.
Chose the in-group person. The trustful relation will benefit the project.
You delegate the decision to a third team member to avoid the conflict.

Question: Which scenarios describes a conflict of interest
Note:
[Qno: PML_2619] >> Option 1- May be un-ethical as per your org policy.
Option 2- As far as you are not going to benefit competitor by providing him inside information that is fine. You are hired by competitor for your talent, skill, hardwork, attitude not for giving internal information.
Option 3- This is your personal matter, discussing with other colleagues can be issue if it mentioned in your employment contract

Answers: Discussing your work with a friend
Accepting employment from a competitor after leaving your company
Reviewing your salary with your financial planner
Using your company’s information to promote your own business

Question: Which of the following is not a conflict of interest

Answers: Working for competing clients at the same time
Working at the same company where your father works
Accepting a gift from a vendor who is trying to win business from your company
Use of company information to benefit a friend’s business

Question: You are working in an automobile company. Company recently has gone through the rough time due to default of some receivable from market. Company has just come out from the trouble but to improve the efficiencies in future some big changes need to done. For that purpose you contacted some vendor to supply some equipments and software. Payment terms of the vendor explicitly asks for payment within 45 days, but as per confidence your company would not be able to make the payment before 6 months. Vendor has done his due diligence and he did not find this kind of risk in your organization. what should you do?

Answers: Keep silent and award the contract
Postpone the project until you can afford to pay as per the vendor condition
Inform the vendor of your plans; there are other suppliers you can go to if need be
Borrow some money from market and pay to the vendor
